This report was prepared by Ramesh Subramaniam, Senior 
Corporate and Financial Governance Specialist, ECRD.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Tajikistan requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 2001 to 
provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  support  governance  reforms  in  public  and  private 
institutions. The Government and ADB reached an understanding on the objectives, scope, and 
cost, financing, and implementation arrangements for the proposed TA during a Fact-Finding 
Mission in August 2002. The TA is included in the 2002 TA program. The logical framework is in 
Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Civil conflicts as well as structural rigidities have delayed Tajikistan’s transition to a 
market-oriented economy. As an indicator, total output in 2001 was only 43% of that in 1991. 
Since the resumption of peace in 1997, the economy has steadily been recovering and real 
gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 8.3% in 2000 and 10.3% in 2001. Inflation has gone 
down from levels above 120% in 1997 to less than 40% in 2001. The foreign exchange rate has 
stayed relatively stable since the introduction of the somoni (TJS) in October 2000, (TJS1 
replaced 1,000 Tajik rubles). In 2000, the Government accelerated the privatization of state-
owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  and  strengthened  tax  administration,  budget  management  and 
treasury systems. Agriculture sector reforms are gradually under way. Yet growth opportunities 
remain limited with two principal products (aluminium and cotton) driving the economy, thus 
making it vulnerable to terms of trade shocks and poor harvests. The large volume of external 
debt outstanding at 97% of GDP at end-2001 hinders medium-term growth. 
 
3.  As in the other small transition economies, the financial sector of Tajikistan remains 
small and nascent. The banking sector comprises 14 domestic commercial banks and 1 branch 
of a foreign-owned bank. At the end of 2001, the deposit base of the banking sector stood at 
TJS183 million ($76.4 million) or 7.3% of GDP, its assets amounted to 18.4% of GDP, while 
loans  accounted  for  15.5%  of  GDP.  Exhibiting  high  concentration,  the  four  largest  banks 
account for 86% of the assets, 91% of loans, and about 95% of the deposits. Of the four, 
Agroinvest Bank, the largest, accounts for more than 80% of the outstanding loans.  
 
4.  The Law on National Bank and the Law on Banks and Banking Activity (LBBA), adopted 
in 1992 and amended subsequently in 1998, along with a host of National Bank of Tajikistan 
(NBT) regulations, define the legal and regulatory framework governing the banking sector. 
While the laws give adequate authority to NBT, inconsistencies between these laws and the 
new Civil Code adopted in 1999 have impeded effective regulation. Public confidence in the 
banking system has been low and declining. Although NBT requires some evidence of financial 
status from shareholders, the legal and regulatory framework does not lay down stringent 
corporate and financial governance (CFG) requirements. Specifically, there are no provisions 
with respect to (i) representation of independent members on the board of directors (BOD); 
(ii) ongoing fit and proper, and financial disclosure requirements; (iii) establishment of obligatory 
committees of the BOD for risk management and director nominations; (iv) explicit fiduciary 
responsibilities for members of the BOD or the management, to ensure depositors' interests are 
protected; (v) rules on avoiding conflicts of interest by the BOD and the management; and 
(vi) non  preferential  treatment  given  to  transactions  with  related  parties  vis-à-vis  unrelated 
parties. 
 
                                  
 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities in September 2001. An updated version was published in 
August 2002.

2   
5.  The SOE privatization and restructuring process have been gradual. Privatization is 
defined as the sale, through auctions or tenders, of at least 75% of shares in SOEs. In 1991, the 
State had full ownership in 10,280 enterprises, of which 1,084 entities were not privatized given 
their strategic importance. Of the total, 8,562 were classified as small (less than 99 workers) 
and the remaining 1,718 were categorized either as medium size (100-199 workers) or large 
(more than 200 workers). A case-by-case privatization approach has been adopted for 1,127 
enterprises and 294 farms. Substantial progress has been made with regard to small SOEs, 
with 92% already privatized. However, medium-size and large SOEs have been privatized at a 
much slower pace due to overvaluation of government assets, vested interests impeding the 
process, social concerns, and high indebtedness of many enterprises. Of the 909 medium size 
and  large  SOEs  that  are  subject  to  privatization,  only  466  have  been  privatized  to  date. 
Progress has been made in the first half of 2002, when 100 medium-size and large SOEs were 
privatized, compared with about 75 privatized on average per year over 1998-2001. 
 
6.  Besides LBBA, the key laws governing enterprises are the law on joint-stock companies 
(JSCs) adopted in 1991 and amended in 1998, law on securities and stock exchange adopted in 
1992 and amended in 1998, law on state enterprises (1993), the Civil Code (1999), and the law 
on limited-liability companies (2002). While Tajikistan has a modern version of the Civil Code in 
relation to its neighboring countries, which had adopted their civil codes at the turn of the 
transition, its commercial laws are yet to be amended to achieve consistency with the Civil 
Code. The law on JSCs defines adequately the grounds for creating and liquidating companies, 
requirements  regarding  charter  capital,  issuance  and  placement  of  securities,  and  some 
principles for disclosure. However, the JSC law lacks specific requirements on CFG. The law 
lacks  (i)  clarity  on  transactional  rights  and  obligations  of  the  BOD  and  the  management; 
(ii)   clear  rules  on  business  judgment  which  may  place  excess  liability  on  the  BOD  or 
management and lead to inaction; (iii) provisions for fiduciary responsibilities on the part of the 
BOD  and  management  to  protect  the  interests  of  shareholders,  particularly  minority 
shareholders; (iv) clarity on the powers of majority shareholders to veto the decisions of the 
BOD  and  management,  without  due  course  to  a  general  meeting  of  all  shareholders; 
(v) adequate provisions governing valuation of shares, and conversion of categories of shares 
(for example, from preferred to ordinary shares); (vi) provisions for debt-to-equity swaps; and 
(vii) requirements on representation of independent directors on the BOD. 
 
7.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has a State Department of Securities Market with a staff 
of only four officials responsible for monitoring over 1,000 registered JSCs. MOF also has a 
Share Registration Department that has registered the shares of about 600 JSCs thus far. While 
the rules establishing these departments stipulate that they will function in an independent 
manner, they are not self-sufficient and rely on support from MOF’s operational budget. The 
Government does not have an independent body to oversee compliance with the provisions of 
legislation pertaining to JSCs. 
 
8.  Tajikistan has the smallest capital market within the Central Asian region. The Central 
Stock Exchange established in 1994 has not played any major role in developing the securities 
market. Privatization has not led to the development of a securities market, as most transactions 
have been conducted through auctions or sale outside of an organized stock exchange. Much of 
the auction process for sale of state property has taken place under the Republican Real Estate 
Market, founded by the State Property Committee (SPC). The enterprises privatized, whether 
through auctions or purchase by strategic investors, have not yet initiated any new share issues. 
There has been no formal secondary trading in the shares held by individual or institutional 
investors, although anecdotal evidence suggests that significant share trading does take place 
informally. Trading in cotton and other commodities takes place at the Tajik Universal and Raw 
Materials Exchange, established in June 2001.

3
9.  SOEs  are  overseen  by  their  respective  sector  ministries.  The  SPC  confines  itself 
primarily to privatization of state property, and does not have adequate capacity to undertake in-
depth  operational  reviews.  The  State  Agency  on  Anti-Monopoly  and  Support  for 
Entrepreneurship  (SAASE),  established  in  2000,  has  the  mandate  for  private  sector 
development and formulates competition policies and examines concentration of market power. 
While reforms have been under way to corporatize all SOEs reporting to various ministries as 
well as to delink policy formulation and day-to-day administration, in reality governance in SOEs 
is weak and significant impediments remain through influence exerted by the line ministries. 
Furthermore, there is no regulatory authority to examine violations by SOEs of company laws or 
governance norms. 
 
10.  Operational and financial problems of privatized enterprises and SOEs exacerbate their 
governance  weaknesses.  An  assessment  of  the  reported  finances  of  about  350  SOEs, 
undertaken with support from the World Bank’s second institutional building TA loan, reveals 
that none of the enterprises have been operational over the last 3 years. With the exception of a 
few engaged in aluminum production or raw cotton processing, enterprises in other sectors 
have incurred consecutive losses. Most private JSCs as well as SOEs operate well below their 
capacities, and anecdotal evidence indicates significant asset stripping by insiders. Inadequate 
and  expensive  means  of  financial  intermediation  have  stymied  effective  restructuring  or 
reorganization of assets. Moreover, the law on bankruptcy, adopted in 1993 and amended most 
recently in 1998, is inadequate in many respects. In contrast to the bankruptcy legislation in the 
neighboring transition economies, the law in Tajikistan is much simpler, but it also lacks clear 
provisions  with  regard  to  bankruptcy  determination  and  methods  of  reorganization,  among 
others. In practice, only three cases of bankruptcy have been reported, and none has gone 
through the court system. Given the overall economic difficulties, enterprises are reluctant to 
pursue  restructuring  or  bankruptcy  as  options.  In  the  absence  of  sound  asset  valuation 
practices, enterprises tend to inflate their assets to avoid bankruptcy, even if they had defaulted 
on debt repayment or other obligations.  
 
11.  The World Bank has actively supported restructuring of the banking sector under its first 
structural adjustment credit in 1996,2 and privatization of enterprises under its second structural 
adjustment  credit  in  2000.3 ADB  has  supported  (i)  the  initial  phase  of  law  reform  and 
dissemination of legal information,4 and (ii) corporatization of key enterprises in the transport 
and energy sectors.5  
 
12.  The United States Agency for International Development and the Swiss Development 
Cooperation  Agency  have  provided  substantial  legal  and  judicial  training.  However,  no 
significant external support has yet been provided to assess the state of CFG in banks or 
commercial enterprises, develop the corporate sector or to strengthen enterprise reorganization 
measures, for which the Government has requested the proposed TA. It will be implemented in 
coordination with the work being done by the other aid agencies. The lessons emerging from 
the ADB TA on law reform point to the need for (i) improving coordination of legal and judicial 
reforms, (ii) wider dissemination of laws, and (iii) training of lawyers and judges. The proposed 
TA will help disseminate the provisions of the law on bankruptcy and bankruptcy procedures 
widely in the legal community through several training workshops.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
13.  The goal of the TA is to strengthen CFG in Tajikistan. The purpose is to (i) strengthen 
the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  with  regard  to  CFG  in  commercial  banks;  (ii) support 
corporate  sector  development;  (iii)  enhance  institutional  capacity  to  undertake  enterprise 
restructuring initiatives; and (iv) formulate reform directions to guide the Government in the 
areas of (i)-(iii).  
 
14.  The outputs will include (i) revised legal and regulatory provisions on CFG in commercial 
banks, CFG assessments, and recommendations to strengthen supervisory capacity in this area; 
(ii) training modules on corporate management; (iii) a developmental and regulatory framework 
for the securities market; and (iv) capacity-building initiatives on bankruptcy and enterprise 
restructuring aimed at enhancing the capacity of lawyers, judges, court officials, and special 
administrators. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
15.  The TA will pursue activities in two areas. 
 
1.  Strengthen CFG in the Banking Sector 
(i)  Strengthen  CFG-related  provisions  in  LBBA  and  other  commercial  banking 
regulations, with specific focus on (a) effective management of various types of 
risks; (b) fit-and-proper qualification requirements for principal shareholders and 
members  of  the  BOD  and  the  management; (c)  constitution  of  obligatory 
committees of the BOD for risk management, managerial compensation, and 
director  nominations;  (d)  presence  of  independent  directors  on  the  BOD; 
(e) establishment of an explicit fiduciary duty for banks, members of the BOD and 
the management; (f) disclosure of the financial interests of members of the BOD 
and the management; (g) rules to avoid exploitation of conflict of interest by 
directors and managers; and (h) nonpreferential treatment of banks' transactions 
with related parties. 
 
(ii)  Assess the current state of CFG practices in all commercial banks and formulate 
and introduce guidelines on CFG in all commercial banks, amend the internal 
regulations of NBT and strengthen supervisory procedures to effectively enforce 
CFG requirements, and help banks in implementing the guidelines. 
 
2.  Formulate a Sound Developmental Framework for the Corporate Sector 
(i)  Strengthen relevant provisions within the law on JSCs to improve CFG, and 
formulate a sound regulatory framework for JSCs.  
 
(ii)  Strengthen the Law on Bankruptcy to facilitate efficient enterprise restructuring 
initiatives and to expedite bankruptcy procedures. 
 
(iii)  Enhance the institutional capacity of the SPC to monitor progress with regard to 
bankruptcy;  and  give  training  on  bankruptcy  and  enterprise  reorganization 
procedures  for  lawyers,  judges,  court  officials,  accountants,  special 
administrators, and other finance sector professionals.

5
 
(iv)  Design and implement a pilot program covering at least 50 enterprises registered 
as  JSCs  to  (a)  train  senior  officials  in  modern  corporate  management,  and 
(b) formulate efficient operational or financial restructuring measures to enhance 
viability. 
 
(v)  Based on an assessment of the medium-term economic outlook and need for 
long-term financing requirements, provide advisory and capacity-building support 
to the Government to design a developmental plan and regulatory framework for 
the securities market.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $565,000 equivalent, of which $412,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $153,000 equivalent is the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $480,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$68,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the balance of the 
local  currency  cost,  equivalent  to  $85,000,  through  the  provision  of  counterpart  staff  and 
workshop facilities. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Spain. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will select and engage a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method 
and a simplified technical proposal in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. Consulting services 
will total 33 person-months (11 international, 22 domestic). Consultants will have expertise in 
(i) CFG legal and regulatory framework, (ii) corporate sector development and restructuring, and 
(iii) capacity building in bankruptcy procedures. The outline terms of reference for consulting 
services are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  Given the overall focus on financial and corporate sector development, MOF will be the 
Executing Agency for the TA and will implement the JSC development component jointly with 
SAASE and SPC. NBT will be the Implementing Agency for the banking sector component. The 
Ministry  of  Justice  (MOJ)  along  with  SPC  will  be  responsible  for  the  subcomponents  on 
bankruptcy procedures. A bankruptcy reform group will be established, with participation from 
SPC, MOJ, and MOF. To ensure effective coordination among all agencies, MOF will establish 
a steering committee with participation from MOJ, NBT, SPC, and SAASE. The TA is expected 
to start in March 2003; it will be implemented over a period of 10 months.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $480,000 to the Government 
of Tajikistan to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Spain for Strengthening 
Corporate and Financial Governance Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  Technical  Assistance  (TA)  will  provide  advisory  services  of  33  person-months: 
11 international  and  22  domestic.  The  terms  of  reference  (TORs)  are  provided  to  outline 
indicative tasks, and the consultants will be required to undertake any other related tasks to 
attain the objectives of the TA. The international consultants will formulate detailed TORs for the 
domestic experts and oversee the latter’s inputs in the respective components. While the team 
leader is responsible for providing consolidated reports on all components of the TA, all the 
other consultants will be required to submit written reports on their respective components. 
 
A.  International Consultants  
1.  Corporate  Sector  Development  &  Restructuring  Expert/Team  Leader 
(7.5 person-months)  
2.  The expert will be a well-qualified financial analyst/economist/management specialist, 
with significant experience in (i) enterprise-level operational and financial performance analysis, 
(ii)  sound  management  practices  to  attain  and  sustain  corporate  viability,  (iii)  enterprise 
restructuring measures that need to be adopted by firms facing difficulties, and (iv) general 
policy and institutional framework for capital market development. The expert will coordinate the 
TA work with the Ministry of Finance (MOF), State Property Committee (SPC), and the State 
Agency on Anti-monopoly and Support for Entrepreneurship (SAASE) for the analytical and 
training components, and with the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) for the component on training legal 
professionals, judges and other court system officials on bankruptcy procedures. The expert will 
undertake various related tasks under the following categories: 
 
a.  General 
(i)  Formulate the terms of reference and tasks for the domestic consultants on 
corporate sector development and bankruptcy issues, and oversee their work. 
(ii)  Coordinate the work of the two other international consultants in an effective 
manner, and integrate their findings into the component on enterprise sector 
development; and 
(iii)  Prepare a comprehensive report on all the components of the TA, with focus on 
day-to-day corporate sector management issues as well as the need for efficient 
restructuring  modalities;  formulate  a  matrix  of  policy  reforms,  based  on  the 
sequence of measures identified in item (ix). 
 
b.  Overall Corporate Sector Development 
(iv)  Prepare a position paper (based on work conducted by other agencies, and initial 
interviews and enterprise-level visits) on the operational and financial state of 
medium-size and large joint-stock company (JSCs), both state-owned as well as 
privatized; assess the critical training needs, and identify the key areas where 
advisory support to enterprises will be needed in terms of day-to-day corporate 
management and development; formulate policy and regulatory measures that 
the Government can adopt to address the most pressing constraints that impede 
the growth of the corporate sector; and 
(v)  Design and implement a pilot program covering at least 50 medium-size and 
large JSCs registered with MOF (private as well as state-owned), and design all 
necessary training modules and materials, to (a) train senior officials in modern 
corporate  management,  and  (b)  formulate  efficient  operational  or  financial

undertaken in separate modules and spread over the duration of the TA. 
 
c.  Support for Enterprise Restructuring 
 
(vi)  Evaluate  the  role  of  the  Government  in  enterprise  restructuring  (including 
bankruptcy) measures and complications arising from its position as a creditor as 
provider of budgetary loans and other financial support, or tax and social security 
arrears. 
(vii)  Enhance the capacity of the SPC to monitor progress with regard to bankruptcy 
and  formulate  measures  to  promote  automatic,  self-initiated  enterprise-
restructuring measures; and 
(viii)  Design and undertake at least three awareness building and intensive training 
workshops on bankruptcy and enterprise reorganization procedures for lawyers, 
judges,  court  officials,  accountants,  special  administrators,  and  other  finance 
sector professionals. 
  
d.  Forward-Looking Corporate Sector Measures 
 
(ix)  Based on an assessment of the current market potential, medium-term economic 
outlook, and need for long-term financing, design a developmental framework for 
the securities market; provide advisory and capacity-building support to MOF and 
other relevant agencies on securities market development; in particular, assess 
the potential for primary market development through privatization and issuance 
of shares on the relevant stock exchanges; and 
(x)  Formulate  a  proper  sequence  of  policy  and  institutional  reform  measures  to 
strengthen the corporate sector in Tajikistan, including an assessment of the 
likely resource requirements and fiscal implications of financing the policy and 
institutional changes.  
 
2.  Banking Sector Corporate Governance Expert (2 person-months) 
3.  The  expert  will  be  well-qualified  with  significant  prior  experience  in  comparable 
economies. The expert will focus on financial as well as enterprise sectors, and will undertake 
the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review Law on Banks and Banking Activity, Law on Central Bank and other laws 
relevant to commercial banking and central bank, with a view to strengthen the 
corporate and financial governance (CFG) provisions, with focus on effective 
management  of  various  types  of  risks;  fit-and-proper  requirements  for  all 
commercial bank directors and officials; formation of obligatory committees of 
BOD for risk management, managerial compensation, and director nominations; 
and explicit fiduciary duties of officials of commercial banks.  
(ii)  Assess the current state of CFG practices in all commercial banks, against the 
existing requirements imposed by National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT) through laws 
and  regulations,  and  categorize  commercial  banks  by  their  CFG  outcomes; 
formulate remedial measures for those in violation of some of the fundamental

(iii)  Formulate and circulate guidelines on CFG to all commercial banks; and amend

3.  Corporate Sector Legal and Regulatory Expert (1.5 person-months) 
4.  The expert will be a qualified legal professional, with significant work experience in the 
corporate sector as well as in enterprise restructuring issues. The expert will work with the MOF, 
SPC and MOJ in undertaking the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Provide advisory support to strengthen the law on JSCs, particularly with regard 
to CFG provisions, in coordination with the ongoing efforts to amend the relevant 
legislation.  
(ii)  Critically evaluate the amendments being drafted to the Law on Bankruptcy to 
ensure that the final version of the law contains sufficient provisions to initiate as 
well as expedite bankruptcy and enterprise reorganization procedures.  
(iii)  Assess the current capital market regulatory framework, as implemented by the 
State Department of Securities Market, and the Share Registration Department 
within the MOF, and formulate recommendations to strengthen the regulatory 
approaches and philosophy.  
(iv)  Give the team leader any advisory support needed in the legal and regulatory 
areas. 
(v)  Provide  a  sequence  of  developmental  and  regulatory  measures  needed  to 
promote and sustain a viable capital market. 
(vi)  Prepare a detailed report with recommendations (i)-(v). 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
5.  Four domestic consultants will be recruited for a total of 22 person-months to support the 
work of the international consultants in the following areas: (i) banking sector CFG, 3 person-
months; (ii) corporate sector development for 5.5 person-months; (iii) a bankruptcy training for 6 
person-months; and (iv) office manager to coordinate the administrative arrangements for the 
TA for 7.5 person-months. All domestic consultants will possess significant experience in their 
areas of expertise. They will support the TORs of the international experts. The work of the 
domestic  consultants  will  be  coordinated  and  overseen  by  the  respective  international 
consultants.  The  domestic  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  providing  written  inputs  and 
reports on their respective components. 
 
C.  Reporting Arrangements 
6.  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  preparing  brief  monthly  progress  reports, 
providing updates on implementation, until the project is completed. In addition, an interim 
report will be submitted 2 months after the initiation of the TA (which could be combined in an 
enhanced monthly report), and a draft final report, 2 weeks before completion of the tasks for 
the TA. The draft final report will be revised and resubmitted, incorporating comments from the 
Government and ADB.
